etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in The Wycliffite Bible (early version). In some forms from the genitive of cock + crowing

definitions: Dawn or another time in the early morning marked by the crowing of cockerels or roosters; = "cockcrow". Now somewhat rare.

notes.text: In early use sometimes with preceding qualifying word indicating a time in the early morning; compare "first (also second, third) cock".

definitions: The crowing of a cockerel or rooster. Also (and in earliest use): an instance of this.
